label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, July 14, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing a game of tennis he and Morris played, reporting the joy on the island over the end of the blackouts, and recounting the stories of he and Morris’s search for a house to buy. Sidney continues in his letter to describe one of the houses they had viewed with their real estate agent.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing a game of tennis he and Morris played, reporting the joy on the island over the end of the blackouts, and recounting the stories of he and Morris’s search for a house to buy. Sidney continues in his letter to describe one of the houses they had viewed with their real estate agent.

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications
metadata.value: 300 dpi, 24-bit depth color, Epson Expression 10000XL, Archival Masters are tiffs.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
22
July 14, 1943
Dear Gertie,
What a wonderful sight you missed this evening.
Morris and I decided that we did not want to go swimming
and played tennis instead at the Royal Hawaiian. You know
how two fat jews look the morning after they have arrived at
a summer hotel. They go to the court with a string bag full
of gray, dead balls and funny shaped rackets th t they have
borrowed from a friend who played the previous summer. They
wear very short shorts and theirderriers stick out behind and
their stomachs fall over the front of the shorts. They talk
a great deal about "vell hit the ball vy doan yon hit it"
and that is as far as their game goes. Ours was just the
same. A terrifc battle in which there were no rallies. I was
beaten seven to five and we had to help each other off the court
Never have I felt so awarkward and clumsy. The r[A]_cket felt
like some strange unknown instrument in my hand, and my feet
and legs were like those of that Frenchmans who kept crying
at Vichy th t he had "les jambes coupes" However sitting
in my room and trying to cool off as I write this I fee[l] one
hundred times better than I have ever done after swimming.
It is such a different form of exercise. Tennis makes your
blood circulate and your muscles move. Swimming you just
float along blowing bubbles without ever even taking a deep
breath. I hope we will play some more, but I don't know, it
is sort of hard to get the old man out on the court.
Last night was mardi Gras in Honolulu. We were all wed
to have our lights on providing the shades were pulled down
below the levels of the lights. Crowds walked up and down
ohing and ahing at the lights and it gave me a great thrill
to see them again. They looked so strange, one felt instincteiv
something was wrong and your first instict was to yell " hey
your light is showing" No one sat i[N] their living rooms as they
were all outside walking around looking into other peoples
living rooms. Then a funny thing happened. Suddenly the lights
began to go out and in their place the dim black out bulbs came
on. People could not stand the bright lights in their eyes.
They were to glary, and not nerely [A]s peacful as the faint
glow of the other bulbs. I tried to sit in our l ving room
with the lights on but they gave me the jum s, so I ended by
turning them off and going into my bedroom and reading there
as I have been doing for the past eleventh months. Eleventh
months. Think of that. Almost a year out here. A year away
from you. You and I who have ne er been seperated, who moved
as one. It seems incredible that this happened and continues to
happen. I thihk of youall the time dear, wonder what you are
[End Page 1]
doing and what we are going to do when this war is over.
I went out to see A Mr Daltons house which is for sale on
Sunday. There was a spaniel there that absolutely broke
my heart. He did everythingClippy use to do. Ran in c rcles,
sneezed and put his paws up. I wanted to hug him so badly.
This house is for sale. Morris and I go every Sunday morning wit
a real estate dealer to see different houses. In this way we hop
to get and idea what prices should be and why. As yet I have
not the slightest idea. The Topping house which sold with all
its furniture, tennis court, swimming pool and lovely grounds
for fifty thousand was one price. Lester McCoys house is
for sale for two hundred and twenty five thousand andis not
nearly as attractive. No tennis court or swimming pool and 
very dark and dreary.
Mr Daltons House is at Kahala. You turn left from
the roads towards the sea and [p]ass between two fat gate posts.
Immediately on the leftt is a tennis court[,] the backstops
heave with star jasmine. To your right are clumps of white and
purple oleander bushes through when you catch glimpses of lawns
and enormous shade trees. The road curves around a clump of tall
palms and rejoins itself. We left the car here and went through
an opening in a Hibiscus hedge [to] find ourselves facing the
blue waters of a swimming pool shimmering in the sun while beyond
across a stretch of green grass the sea rolled in in great white
combers over the reef. To the left at the end of the pool
was a little palm th tched hut in the shade of which blue chairs
sat as if mirroring the w ters of the pool. At one side of the
but was a tiny bar made rom a surfboard. We left this scene
of delight and turning to our right away from the pool passed
between some yellow flowering bushes and into the house itslef.
There is noth ng to tell. It was cery dissapointing. Rooms all
cho[p]ped up and filled with french furniture. Cornices and mantel
pieces that the owner informed us with pride were brought from
the mainland. Machine made copies of charleston rooms, can you
imagine it, here in this tropical island. A land of staw mats
and bamboo furniture, to have such atrocitires. But I did not
really look at the house because the spaniel was bouncing around
begging to be taken for a walk and snuffling under all the
beds[,]as if he did not know very well there was nothing there.
We went [scratched through] out into the garden which was lovely.
Now so large that one man could not take care of it, but at the
same time it gave a great feeling of space. Something that I din
one misses here shut in as you are by the heavy vegetation.
The lawn wove and curved betwenn and around lovely flowering bush
hes and the[N]belled out [to] sorrounded an enormous shade tree,
a lovely old th ng whose trunk was covered with the shiny leaves
of some vine and tiny little orchids that seemed to fl[o]at in the
air. To one side was a little ro[c]k pool almost hidden by the
flowers and creepers [scratched through] [at] its sides. It was full of xx
shadows and lights out of which tiny little [fis]hes darted and
dissappeared almost as fast as flickers of l ght themselves.
[End Page 2]
At the end of seeing all and Morris finding that he knew many
people that Mr Dalton did, Mr Lewis Thompson, Pussy Thompsons
father in Redbank, Tom McCarter etc. We asked the price.
Only two hundred and ten thousand to us as we were almost old
friends. By the by he said Pussy had married a professor who
was teaching at Princeton .
I received a copy of a letter from Miss Finucan to you
dated June 24th. Is she still with us or have you fired her.
Please be sure and number y ur letters when you get to England
as I know I am missing lots of them as you contiual refer in
one letter to something that I have never heard from you about.
Goodbye darling. I send you all my love and best wishes
for your trip. God bless and keep you until I can hold you
in my arms again. 
Sidney J Legendre
PS I sent you two letters one dated Julu 11th. and one
July 12th. I forgot to number them so please put the
follwing numbers on themif they have been received
in order that you may check and see if any are missing.
[End Page 3]
